# Introduction

DBmaps simplifies the analysis of relational database structures by automating table merging operations. This vignette demonstrates the package's core functionality for merging multiple tables efficiently.

## Installation

```{r installation, eval=FALSE}
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("I-am-Sagar/DBmaps")
library(DBmaps)
```

# Merging Tables with DBmaps

The `merge_all_tables()` function allows you to merge three tables in one operation. Here's how to use it:

```{r example}
# Load sample data
data(students)
data(scores)
data(attendance)

# Perform a three-way merge
result <- merge_all_tables(
  students, 
  scores, 
  attendance,
  by_col = "id",
  merge_type = "inner",
  final_merge_type = "inner"
)

head(result)
```

## Merge Types

DBmaps supports four merge types: - `"inner"`: Matches only common rows - `"left"`: Keeps all rows from first table - `"right"`: Keeps all rows from second table - `"full"`: Keeps all rows from both tables

Example with different merge types:

```{r merge_example}
# Left join followed by full join
result_alt <- merge_all_tables(
  students, 
  scores, 
  attendance,
  merge_type = "left",
  final_merge_type = "full"
)
```

# Best Practices

1.  Verify unique identifiers in your key columns
2.  Check for NA values in final dataset
3.  Consider merge order for optimal results
